awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Cuts, Connectivity and Partitioning in Graphs, Hypergraphs and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphs and networks are ubiquitous in computer science, artificial intelligence, and social sciences. Many real-life applications, such as reliability in communication networks and clustering in social networks, can be modeled as partitioning problems in graphs and related structures. For example, finding the minimum number of base stations in a wireless network whose disruption will disconnect communication between two given agents, and finding groups of people in a social network that have strong ties amongst themselves when compared to outsiders, can both be modeled as partitioning problems. This project aims to design new efficient algorithms for fundamental partitioning problems in structures that generalize graphs. The project will drive the integration of generalized graph models in several courses currently taught by the PIs in Computer Science and Industrial Engineering. Lecture notes from these courses and codes of algorithms developed as part of this project will be made publicly available. The project will support two or more PhD students. The PIs are working with students from under-represented groups and will continue to make efforts to recruit additional graduate and undergraduate students to diversify the population of researchers in theoretical computer science. The PIs plan to organize the Midwest Theory Day at their institution in the near future to bring together a broad cross-section of researchers and students.

Cuts, connectivity and partitioning problems in graphs are a central topic in combinatorial optimization and theoretical computer science. While undirected graphs have been extensively studied previously, the primary goal of this project is to address these problems in more complex structures including directed graphs, hypergraphs, and submodular set functions. The complexity status of several problems in these richer models is open. The PIs will investigate polynomial-time solvability, structural results such as sparsification, approximation algorithms, improved running times, and the development of deterministic algorithms where only randomized algorithms are currently known.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Graphs and hypergraphs are ubiquitous in applications. Submodularity is a unifying and powerful framework in discrete and combinatorial optimization, and in particular, the cut function of graphs and hypergraphs are submodular. Partitioning problems over graphs, hypergraphs, and submodular functions arise in a number of applications. In this project, the PIs designed efficient algorithms for such partitioning problems and resolved several long-standing open problems. These results were made possible by new structural results and algorithmic techniques in graphs. Prominent results from the project include the following: 

(1) The PIs and co-authors showed a generalization of Karger’s random contraction technique from graphs to hypergraphs and exploited it to design a randomized polynomial-time algorithm for the hypergraph k-cut problem for fixed k. They also used the random contraction technique to address algorithmic and counting problems concerning multicriteria cuts in graphs and hypergraphs. These results led to the first strongly polynomial bounds on the number of multicriteria cuts.

(2) The PIs gave the first deterministic polynomial-time algorithm for hypergraph k-cut for fixed k by proving a novel structural result for hypergraphs. They exploited this technique to also give the first polynomial-time algorithm for min-max symmetric submodular k-partitioning for every fixed k. As a special case, this leads to the first polynomial-time algorithm for min-max hypergraph k-partition for fixed k. The PIs with student co-authors used the structural results underlying this technique to enumerate all optimum solutions for various hypergraph partitioning problems as well as near-optimum solutions for graph min-cut.

(3) The PIs and co-authors designed faster randomized algorithms for computing global (and subset) connectivity in a number of settings including hypergraphs, element connectivity and vertex connectivity in graphs, and for symmetric submodular functions. They showed that representing symmetric submodular functions using hypergraph cut functions will incur a substantially large inaccuracy. 

Results from this project were published in well-known journals and conferences in Computer Science and Mathematical Optimization. The PIs and students in the project have disseminated the results by giving several presentations. The project supported the supervision and training of several PhD and undergraduate students and two PhD students graduated with dissertations based on the results of the project. The PIs have taught advanced graduate courses on graph algorithms and combinatorial optimization and made the extensive lecture notes publicly available as a resource for others to build upon.
